::: {.question-block}
<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module3_mcq_q52')" data-correct-answer="D">
<strong style="display: block;">
An analyst re-estimates a stock’s beta each quarter using a rolling window. 
The stock’s beta has risen from 0.8 to 1.3 over the past year. 
With a risk-free rate of 3% and an expected market return of 10%, what is the CAPM-implied expected return **now**, and what does this imply?
</strong>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q52" value="A"> A. 8.6% — unchanged, because expected return depends on total volatility rather than beta.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q52" value="B"> B. 11.0% — a slight increase; only leverage changes non-systematic risk.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q52" value="C"> C. 12.1% — but the increase reflects higher idiosyncratic (diversifiable) risk.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q52" value="D"> D. 12.1% — equal to 3% + 1.3 × (10% − 3%); a higher beta raises the required return due to greater exposure to market (systematic) risk.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q52" value="E"> E. Cannot be determined without size and value factors.</label><br>
</form>
<div id="feedback-module3_mcq_q52" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: D. With β up from 0.8 to 1.3, CAPM implies E(R) increases from 8.6% to **12.1%**. 
Beta is a **time-varying, estimated** measure of systematic risk (affected by leverage, industry mix, and regimes). 
When β rises, the required return on the SML rises accordingly; idiosyncratic risk does not affect CAPM’s required return.
</div>
:::
